meanings.definition: To torment or tease with the sight or promise of something unobtainable.
meanings.sent1: The bakery would tantalate customers with the smell of fresh bread, but they always sold out before I could buy any.
meanings.sent2: The advertisement tantalated me with images of a tropical vacation, making me dream of sandy beaches and clear blue waters.
meanings.sent3: My friend loves to tantalate me by waving a delicious chocolate bar in front of my face, but never sharing it.
meanings.sent4: The elusive treasure chest tantalated the pirates, gleaming in the moonlight but always just out of reach.
meanings.sent5: The aroma of freshly baked cookies tantalated my senses, making my mouth water in anticipation.

meanings.definition: To excite the senses or desires of someone.
meanings.sent1: The vibrant colors of the painting tantalated my eyes, drawing me in with their beauty.
meanings.sent2: The music tantalated my ears, filling the room with melodious notes that lifted my spirits.
meanings.sent3: The delicious smell of dinner tantalated our noses, making us eagerly await the meal.
meanings.sent4: The thrilling movie trailer tantalated my excitement, making me eager to see the full film.
meanings.sent5: The cool breeze tantalated my skin, bringing relief on a hot summer day.

meanings.definition: To provoke someone by showing them something desirable but keeping it out of reach.
meanings.sent1: The magician tantalated the audience by making a coin disappear and reappear in his hand.
meanings.sent2: The store display tantalated shoppers with the latest gadgets, but they were all out of stock.
meanings.sent3: The chef tantalated the guests by preparing a mouth-watering dessert but then serving it to another table.
meanings.sent4: The fashion designer tantalated fashionistas with a sneak peek of the new collection before its official release.
meanings.sent5: The author tantalated readers with a cliffhanger ending, leaving them eager for the next book in the series.
